title: AGL revives data ambitions with telco acquisition
text:
AGL Energy has struck a deal to acquire regional telco player Southern Phone Company in a vastly scaled-down move to achieve its ambitions to expand into data services after its abandoned $3 billion takeover approach for Vocus Group.

The transaction would see AGL pay $27.5 million to acquire all the shares of Southern Phone, which has 100,000 customers across the country, from the existing owners of 35 local councils. The deal is still subject to acceptance from the councils.

AGL CEO Brett Redman has shifted to a smaller scale entry into data services. Janie Barrett

AGL chief executive Brett Redman said the utility's first step into the broadband and data sector "builds on our strong regional presence as an energy retailer and SPC’s telecommunication services and capabilities."

“The acquisition allows us to create space for new products and services that meet the needs of increasingly connected customers as energy and data converge," Mr Redman said.

AGL signalled at its full-year results in August that it was pursuing alternative options to expand into data services after dropping the takeover approach for Vocus in June. The Vocus approach was widely regarded by AGL investors as a high-risk deal although AGL said at the time that negative feedback hadn't been a factor in the decision to walk away, rather than the company was no longer confident that an acquisition on the proposed terms would create value for shareholders.
description: The regional telco player offers a smaller scale entry into data provision for households.
